title: 110_s1190
content: The "Connect The Nation Act" may be cited as the official title of this legislation. The "Connect The Nation Act" acknowledges the importance of broadband services for economic development, public safety, healthcare, education, and overall quality of life for Americans. It emphasizes the need for continued progress in broadband deployment to maintain competitiveness and stimulate business and job growth. The Act also highlights the importance of federal support for state efforts to improve broadband data quality and encourages public-private partnerships for further broadband expansion. The "Connect The Nation Act" emphasizes the importance of broadband services for economic development, public safety, healthcare, education, and overall quality of life for Americans. It highlights the need for continued growth of broadband services and information technology for residents and businesses of the Nation. SEC. 3. ENCOURAGING STATE INITIATIVES TO IMPROVE BROADBAND. The State Broadband Data and Development Grant Program aims to ensure affordable and reliable broadband access, improve technology literacy, empower local technology teams, and create an environment conducive to broadband investment. Grants will be awarded by the Secretary of Commerce to eligible entities based on peer review results. The State Broadband Data and Development Grant Program provides grants on a competitive basis to eligible entities for statewide initiatives to track broadband availability. Eligible entities must submit an application and contribute matching funds. The Secretary will require peer review for grant applications. The regulations require technical and scientific peer review groups to review grant applications, provide results to the Secretary of Commerce, and certify confidentiality agreements to prevent unauthorized disclosure of information. Grants awarded must be used by eligible entities for specific purposes. The grant awarded to eligible entities must be used to assess broadband service deployment, track areas with low service levels, identify barriers to adoption, and assess demand and supply for broadband services. The grant aims to meet the demand for services by creating local technology planning teams in each county or designated region. These teams consist of members from various sectors like business, education, healthcare, and government, who benchmark technology use, set goals for improvement, and develop tactical business plans. The grant aims to meet the demand for services by creating local technology planning teams in each county or designated region. Recommendations include online application development, collaboration with broadband service providers, programs to improve computer ownership and Internet access, and collecting detailed market data on broadband service and related technology services. The grant aims to create local technology planning teams to meet broadband service demand. It includes developing online applications, collaborating with service providers, improving computer ownership, and collecting market data. The grant also aims to facilitate information exchange and create a geographic inventory map of broadband service in each state. Eligible entities cannot receive new grants if they have received prior grants for the same activities in the previous 4 years. Each grant recipient must report fund usage to the Secretary of Commerce. An eligible entity is a nonprofit organization chosen by a State to collaborate on identifying and monitoring broadband services. The nonprofit organization must be tax-exempt under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. The curr_chunk discusses the criteria for an eligible entity to receive grants for broadband services, including being a nonprofit organization with no earnings benefiting individuals, having experience in deploying broadband services, and having a board of directors not primarily affiliated with government entities. The term "broadband service" is defined as any service connecting to the public Internet with a data transmission rate of at least 200. The curr_chunk authorizes $40,000,000 for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 for broadband services. It also clarifies that the Act does not grant regulatory authority over broadband service providers.
